text:
You want to be sun-safe, but sunscreen
labels are confusing. SPF. UVA. UVB. OMG
We'll explain the science so you don't get burned.
Hey chemkateers. Carmen here.
Summertime means fun in the sun, but this season the U.S. Senate is turning up the

heat on the Food and Drug Administration.
Senators want the FDA to lay down the law

on sunscreen labeling. Anything over
SPF 50,

lawmakers say, should just be labeled as
SPF 50 plus. Why? Sunscreen protection
Sunscreen protection pretty much tops out there. Numbers higher than SPF 50 are just misleading--
and probably a waste of money.

Sophia: Wait! So my SPF 70 spray here isn't extra
awesome?
I was always taught that more is more.
Carmen: Well Sophia, it's complicated. Allow me to shed some light on sunscreen chemistry.

SPF stands for for sun protection factor. Think of a
layer of sunscreen like a really thin

bulletproof vest and the sun's rays as a
barrage of bullets.

Sunscreens absorb or reflect UV
radiation from the sun before it can

penetrate your skin and give you a
sunburn or, even worse, skin cancer.

Chemists have a measurement
called absorbance. In the lab, you can

shine a light on something and then
figure out how much of that light comes

through the other side. You can test
sunscreens the same way.
You'd think that SPF 30 would have two times as much absorbance as SPF 15, but it doesn't.

And look. SPF 50 isn't that much better
than SPF 30.

We're maxing out here, people. Here's
another way of looking at it.

After SPF 50, you're barely getting any more bang
for your buck.

Sky-high numbers might make you think
you're safer, but the evidence says otherwise.

You should also know that no sunscreen
blocks 100% of UV rays.
And one last thing.

SPF only measures how effective
sunscreen is at blocking UVB rays.

UVB rays are the primary cause of sunburn,
but UVA rays penetrate even deeper into your skin.

They're linked to premature aging and
skin cancer and play a role in sunburn, too.

Experts have yet to agree on a system
for measuring UVA ray protection.
For now, there's a pass/fail test. If a sunscreen passes, it gets labeled broad spectrum.
So remember: Apply plenty, reapply often,

and don't waste your money on anything over
SPF 50.

That's Speaking of Chemistry. You can get
more information at cen.acs.org.
